entry.title: My LSTM Network Notes - Training LTSMs

link.title: My LSTM Network Notes - Training LTSMs

entry.content:
Terminology

  • Backpropagation Training Algorithm - the mathematical method used to calculate derivatives and an application of the derivative chain rule and the training algorithm for updating network weights to minimize error. The goal of the backpropagation training algorithm is to modify the weights of a neural network in order to minimize the error of the network outputs compared to some expected output in response to corresponding inputs.
    1. Present a training input pattern and propagate it through the network to get an output.
    2. Compare the predicted outputs to the expected outputs and calculate the error.
    3. Calculate the derivatives of the error with respect to the network weights.
    4. Adjust the weights to minimize the error.
    5. Repeat.
  • Backpropagation Through Time - or BPTT, is the application of the Backpropagation training algorithm to Recurrent Neural Networks. In the simplest case, a recurrent neural network is shown one input each time step and predicts one output.
    1. Present a sequence of time steps of input and output pairs to the network.
    2. Unroll the network then calculate and accumulate errors across each time step. 3. Roll-up the network and update weights.
    3. Repeat.

Types

  • No Notes

Observations

  • One of the main problems of BPTT is the high cost of a single parameter update, which makes it impossible to use a large number of iterations.
  • One way to minimize the exploding and vanishing gradient issue is to limit how many time steps before an update to the weights is performed.

Further Reading

  • http://ArXiv.org
  • https://scholar.google.com/

entry.title: My LSTM Network Notes - Intro to LTSMs

link.title: My LSTM Network Notes - Intro to LTSMs

entry.content:
My LSTM Network Notes - Intro to LTSMs

A deep learning technique designed specifically for sequence prediction problems. A type of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) is an RNN architecture specifically designed to address the vanishing gradient problem.

Terminology

  • Sequence prediction attempts to predict elements of a sequence on the basis of the preceding elements
  • Multilayer Perceptrons (MLP's) - classical neural networks, which can be applied to sequence prediction problems. They can approximate a mapping function from input variables to output variables over time, which lends them to forecasting, especially when it comes to the Vanishing Gradient Problem.
  • Recurrent Neural Network - special type of Neural Network designed for sequencing problems. Given a standard feedforward MLP network, an RNN can be thought of as the addition of loops to the architecture. The recurrent connections add state or memory to the network and allow it to learn and harness the ordered nature of observations within input sequences.
  • Vanishing Gradient Problem - training experiments show how difficult this was where the weight update procedure resulted in weight changes that quickly became so small as to have no effect (vanishing gradients) or so large as to result in very large changes or even overflow (exploding gradients)

Types

  • Vanilla LSTM - memory cells of a single LSTM layer are used in a simple network structure.
  • Stacked LSTM - LSTM layers are stacked one on top of another into deep networks.
  • CNN LSTM - A convolutional neural network is used to learn features in spatial input like images and the LSTM can be used to support a sequence of images as input or generate a sequence in response to an image.
  • Encoder-Decoder LSTM - One LSTM network encodes input sequences and a separate LSTM network decodes the encoding into an output sequence.
  • Bidirectional LSTM - Input sequences are presented and learned both forward and backward.
  • Generative LSTM - LSTMs learn the structure relationship in input sequences so well that they can generate new plausible sequences.

Notes

  • LTSM > MLPs
  • Training LTSM's > Training RNN
  • Context info in LTSM's > Context info in RNN
  • In time series forecasting, often the information relevant for making a forecast is within a small window of past observations. Often an MLP with a window or a linear model may be a less complex and more suitable model.
  • An important limitation of LSTMs is the memory. Or more accurately, how memory can be abused. It is possible to force an LSTM model to remember a single observation over a very long number of input time steps. This is a poor use of LSTMs and requiring an LSTM model to remember multiple observations will fail.

Further Reading

  • http://ArXiv.org
  • https://scholar.google.com/

entry.title: My OpenSAML SSO Implementation Notes
entry.content:
Single Sign On (SSO) with OpenSAML

Terminology

  • Federated login - in which a user's single identity, is trusted across multiple IT systems or even organizations.
  • Identity Provider - Identity Provider provides Web Single Sign-On capabilities, authenticating users and supplying data to services
  • Service Provider - in this context, integrates federated login from an identity provider as the point of authentication.

Authentication Flow

There are so many permutations available in SAML, but the gist of it is below.

  • Service Provider intercepts access to a protected resource or application entry point.
  • Service Provider discovers the user’s choice of Identity Provider.
  • Service Provider issues a SAML authentication request to the selected Identity Provider.
  • Identity Provider authenticates the user against the identity provider organization’s existing authentication store(s);
  • Service Provider processes the SAML authentication responses and extracts rich user information.
  • Service Provider applies local policies and gather additional data. (if needed)
